title: Currently available AI tools
text: In this tutorial, we discuss some currently available LLM AI tools and when/how you might want to use them. This is of course a rapidly moving field, so a few months from now things might have changed. I can hopefully keep up somewhat, but check the last modified date of this page üòÅ.

title: Currently available AI tools
text:
Introduction
It seems that every month a new LLM AI tool is announced. They are expected to keep getting better fairly rapidly for the foreseeable future. As you use these tools, it‚Äôs definitely useful to play around and explore. Here, I‚Äôm describing those that seem - as of this writing - the most useful ones for coding and data analysis tasks. Other AI tools might be more suitable for other tasks.

title: Currently available AI tools
text:
In brief
Currently, ChatGPT 4 is the most powerful LLM AI tool. You can access it through a paid subscription via OpenAi, or for free through Microsoft‚Äôs Bing. ChatGPT 3.5 is the less powerful, free version you can access by creating a free OpenAI account. Despite being less powerful, I‚Äôve found it to work pretty well to write R code. Other LLM are worth trying too, e.g.¬†Claude for data exploration/analysis.

title: Currently available AI tools
text:
OpenAI ChatGPT
As of this writing, for the AI tools we are interested in (the LLMs), ChatGPT is probably the most useful tool. You can access it by creating a free account.
ChatGPT is also part of the Microsoft Bing search engine (currently located under the ‚ÄúChat‚Äù tab) and GitHub‚Äôs CoPilot.
If you haven‚Äôt already, I suggest you create a ChatGPT/OpenAI account. As of this writing, you can get a free account. Once you log in, you see a fairly plain interface with an area into which you can type your prompts. You can provide fairly elaborate prompts. We‚Äôll look at examples in other units.

title: Currently available AI tools
text:
Microsoft Copilot/Bing (still OpenAI GPT)
A free OpenAI account gives you access to ChatPGT 3.5. While I find it often quite useful, especially for writing code, it‚Äôs not the best AI out there. ChatGPT 4.0 is generally better. You have to pay OpenAI if you want to use it. Or, you can use Microsoft Copilot - aka Bing Chat, and not to be confused with the GitHub Copilot, which is also owned by Microsoft ü§∑Ô∏è. It is recommended to use it in ‚ÄúCreative‚Äù or ‚ÄúPrecise‚Äù mode. Of course feel free to explore and play around. I will use the terms Microsoft Copilot or Bing AI/Chat interchangably. I‚Äôm sure all these names will change soon again anyway.

title: Currently available AI tools
text:
GitHub Copilot
GitHub Copilot is currently free for students with the GitHub student developer pack I asked you to sign up for. Set it up by following the Quickstart guide.
Once you have Copilot activated, you can use it in R Studio. (It is also possible to use it with other popular editors, such as VS Code, but for this course I will focus on R Studio. If you prefer to code in VS Code, you can install the Copilot plugin).
To get Copilot working in R Studio, follow these instructions. You might want to leave Copilot indexing unchecked for now. The instruction guide explains what this is. Basically, if you check this, copilot can access all files that are part of your current project. This can lead to confidentiality issues. Therefore, only check it if you are sure that all files in your project are ok being shared with the AI (and possibly make their way to Github/Microsoft/OpenAI servers).
Once you have Copilot up and running, you should see it show up in the bottom of your R Studio input window (the top right window where you write code). It will start suggesting things as you type, once you stop for a few seconds. You can set that time in the options.
An introduction to using Copilot can be found in this video by Thomas Mock from Posit/RStudio. In general, if you want bigger chunks of code, it seems currently better to go straight to ChatGPT. Copilot seems most useful to help you write bits of code as you go along. It can also be useful to help you remember the names of functions and arguments. This blog post provides some additional useful information on how to best use Copilot.
In general, I recommend you turn off Copilot in RStudio when you are not actively using it. And before you turn it on, make sure the document you have open, and any other files it might have access to, do not contain information you want to keep private.

title: Currently available AI tools
text:
Claude/Anthropic
Anthropic is another company developing LLM AI tools. Their main AI is called Claude. As for ChatGPT, you can sign up to get a free account. It is apparently not as powerful as ChatGPT. However, it has one nice feature that the free versions of ChatGPT or Bing do not have, namely it lets you upload files. This is useful for data analysis tasks. I‚Äôll show an example of that in the Explore data with AI unit.

title: Currently available AI tools
text:
Other LLM AI
Other companies, such as Google, are also busy creating LLM AIs. I haven‚Äôt tried them yet. Once I do, I‚Äôll add my impressions. If you are using any other LLM for coding or data analysis tasks and find it useful, please let me know.

title: Currently available AI tools
text:
Other tools
It is quite likely that in the future, there will be several LLM AI tools that are used by the majority of users, and then there will be lots of customizations running on top of those. There are already specialized LLM AI tools for lawyers and doctors and other professions that use ChatGPT under the hood. GitHub CoPilot is such a customization for coding. I expect further tools to keep coming out at a fairly rapid pace.
For instance, as you learned from Thomas Mock‚Äôs video above, the chattr R package seems like another great way to use ChatGPT from within R. Unfortunately, as of this writing, I haven‚Äôt been able to get it to work. It is not entirely clear to me based on the information provided on the chattr website, but I think this is because talking to ChatGPT via the API (which is what chattr does) requires a paid account.
I‚Äôm also aware of the chatAI4R R package, but haven‚Äôt tried it yet. My guess is since it likely also talks to ChatGPT through their API, it also requires a paid account. If that‚Äôs not the case and you try it and find it useful, please report back!
As you are probably aware, AI tools are changing rapidly. I‚Äôm writing this in December 2023, you will read this a few months later. It could be that by this point, some new versions of AI tools have come out that are even better. Do explore and if you find some especially promising platform or package, let me know!

text: This assessment walks you through creating a portfolio website. You will set up a GitHub repository from a template, customize Quarto files, and publish the site with GitHub Pages.

title: Portfolio Creation
text:
GitHub repository creation
We will use GitHub to both manage this project and host the website.
To make things a bit easier and faster, we will use a GitHub repository template that already has the necessary Quarto files and configuration. Go to the Online Portfolio Template. Make sure you are logged into GitHub, then click Use this template.
Create a new repository called yourname-portfolio (include both first and last name, e.g., andreashandel-portfolio). Choose a public repository.
Next, clone the repository to your local computer (using e.g.¬†GitHub Desktop). We recommend organizing your local repository folders in some way that works well for you. It‚Äôs generally a bad idea to place repository folders into a local folder that is synced with some other service (e.g., Google Drive/Dropbox/OneDrive.)

Quick local website check
Open the repository as a project. Then open the main index.qmd file. You should see the Preview button in the upper left corner of the editor. Click it to render the website. You should see in the terminal window what Quarto is doing. It is not only rendering the current open .qmd file, but instead all files that are part of this project - which is a Quarto website.
You will likely get an error message during rendering, telling you about missing R packages. Install those packages as needed. Once rendering works without errors and is complete, you should see the website preview in the Viewer pane, or your browser (depending on your settings). If it is in the Viewer pane and you want to see it in your browser, click the Open in Browser button (the box with an arrow pointing out of it, in the upper right of the Viewer pane).
If you get missing package errors, install them and try again. A local preview should open in your browser.

If you cannot see the Build tab, open the Terminal and run quarto render to build the site.



Quarto content creation
Open index.qmd and update the landing page text. This is Markdown, so feel free to experiment with headings, lists, and formatting.
Next, open aboutme.qmd and write a personal introduction:

Describe your background, interests, and experience with data analysis.
Include headings and subheadings.
Add a picture of yourself (store it in the repository and link it).
Add a link to a data-related resource you find interesting, with a short explanation.
Optionally add extra content (tables, video, or other elements).

Save and re-render the site to see your changes.

This portfolio website and everything you put on it is public. Do not post anything you want to keep private.



Website control
Open _quarto.yml. This file controls the site title, navigation, and styling.
Make the following changes:

Update the site title.
Replace URL-TO-THIS-REPOSITORY-HERE with the GitHub URL of your repository.
Try a different theme and optionally a different syntax highlight scheme.


YAML is very sensitive to indentation. A small spacing error can break rendering.



Sending updates to GitHub
Once you are happy with your updates, commit and push them:

Close RStudio/Positron.
Open GitKraken (or your preferred Git client).
Stage changes, write a commit message, and commit.
Push to GitHub.


If you ever need to force push, be aware that it overwrites remote history. It is usually better to resolve merge conflicts instead.



Making the website public
Enable GitHub Pages for the repository:

Go to your repository on github.com.
Open Settings ‚Üí Pages.
Set the branch to main and the folder to /docs.
Save.

Your site URL will look like https://username.github.io/yourname-MADA-portfolio/. It can take a minute for the site to appear.


Update your repository README
Open README.md and add a sentence pointing to your website URL. This is the file people see when they visit your GitHub repository.


General GitHub workflow
In the future, your workflow should be:

Pull latest changes.
Edit and render in RStudio/Positron.
Commit and push with your Git client.

You will use this workflow repeatedly.
